user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_ip_count_lock:
```c
static void
MHD_ip_count_lock (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->master);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->per_ip_connection_mutex);
#else
  (void) daemon;
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->master);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The statement mhd_assert(NULL == daemon->master); is executed when MHD_ip_count_lock is called and therefore is reachable. Even if the mhd_assert macro expands to a no-op in some builds, that is a compile-time removal, not an instance of unreachable code. A true Rule 2.1 violation would be code that can never be executed on any control-flow path (e.g. code after an unconditional return or an infinite loop), which is not the case here.
